title: How to Create a Butterfly Clipart

steps.headline: Start by opening your graphics program.
steps.description: Create a 'New Document' with a size of 800 pixels wide by 600 pixels tall.

steps.headline: Using the "pen" tool, in your program of choice, is useful for creating more complex shapes.
steps.description: Start by creating one of the butterfly's wings with the pen tool. Set the stroke to "3 pixels," and don't worry about a fill at this point.

steps.headline: Make the other side.
steps.description: An easy way to create symmetry in an artwork is to copy and paste like shapes. First, select the original butterfly wing, select 'Copy' (generally located in the 'Edit' menu of a program's toolbar), select 'Paste', and then drag my duplicated wing into place. Now you have a set of wings!

steps.headline: Utilize the 'Circle' or 'Ellipse' tool to add circles for the head and antennae.
steps.description: After selecting the tool, simply click anywhere on the artboard, click and drag to your desired size. Copy and pasting can also come in handy here.

steps.headline: Use a few more overlapping ellipses to easily form the butterfly's body!
Connect the antennae to the butterfly's head, using either the 'Line' tool or the 'Pen' tool.
steps.description: With 2 clicks of the Pen Tool, you can create one antennae connection. After that, copy and paste to apply the same line to the opposing antennae.

steps.headline: Review what you have so far.
steps.description: The graphic looks a but basic and cluttered with all of the overlapping lines, don't you think? That can be fixed by adding 'Fill' colors to the shapes and removing/recoloring the outlines or 'Stroke'.

steps.headline: Select each of the segments that made up the butterfly and add fills of color.
steps.description: You might use brown with a slight red tint, as pictured here (RGB value: #6B4411). You can also change the outline (stroke) color from black to the new brown. In the case of the antennae connections, only the stroke needs to be modified.

steps.headline: Do the wings, too.
steps.description: After applying the same treatment to the wings (this time using a dark red color: #B54B1D), you have a fully colorized digital butterfly!

steps.headline: Use gradient, if desired.
steps.description: This more advanced technique can be applied to fills to create a more natural or interesting colorization. For each wing, you can apply a 'Radial Gradient' combining two colors (a yellow: #D3D400 with a red: #B54B1D) to produce a more naturally colored pair of wings. Check out the final product!

tyn: A mouse (for greater precision when drawing)
A graphics program (Adobe Illustrator and Inkscape are good choices!)
text: Drawing the Outlines Start by opening your graphics program. Create a 'New Document' with a size of 800 pixels wide by 600 pixels tall. Using the "pen" tool, in your program of choice, is useful for creating more complex shapes. Start by creating one of the butterfly's wings with the pen tool. Set the stroke to "3 pixels," and don't worry about a fill at this point. Make the other side. An easy way to create symmetry in an artwork is to copy and paste like shapes. First, select the original butterfly wing, select 'Copy' (generally located in the 'Edit' menu of a program's toolbar), select 'Paste', and then drag my duplicated wing into place. Now you have a set of wings! Utilize the 'Circle' or 'Ellipse' tool to add circles for the head and antennae. After selecting the tool, simply click anywhere on the artboard, click and drag to your desired size. Copy and pasting can also come in handy here. Use a few more overlapping ellipses to easily form the butterfly's body!  Connect the antennae to the butterfly's head, using either the 'Line' tool or the 'Pen' tool. With 2 clicks of the Pen Tool, you can create one antennae connection. After that, copy and paste to apply the same line to the opposing antennae. Cleaning Up and Filling In Review what you have so far. The graphic looks a but basic and cluttered with all of the overlapping lines, don't you think? That can be fixed by adding 'Fill' colors to the shapes and removing/recoloring the outlines or 'Stroke'. Select each of the segments that made up the butterfly and add fills of color. You might use brown with a slight red tint, as pictured here (RGB value: #6B4411). You can also change the outline (stroke) color from black to the new brown. In the case of the antennae connections, only the stroke needs to be modified. Do the wings, too. After applying the same treatment to the wings (this time using a dark red color: #B54B1D), you have a fully colorized digital butterfly! Use gradient, if desired. This more advanced technique can be applied to fills to create a more natural or interesting colorization. For each wing, you can apply a 'Radial Gradient' combining two colors (a yellow: #D3D400 with a red: #B54B1D) to produce a more naturally colored pair of wings. Check out the final product!
sentences: Drawing the Outlines Start by opening your graphics program.
Create a 'New Document' with a size of 800 pixels wide by 600 pixels tall.
Using the "pen" tool, in your program of choice, is useful for creating more complex shapes.
Start by creating one of the butterfly's wings with the pen tool.
Set the stroke to "3 pixels," and don't worry about a fill at this point.
Make the other side.
An easy way to create symmetry in an artwork is to copy and paste like shapes.
First, select the original butterfly wing, select 'Copy' (generally located in the 'Edit' menu of a program's toolbar), select 'Paste', and then drag my duplicated wing into place.
Now you have a set of wings!
Utilize the 'Circle' or 'Ellipse' tool to add circles for the head and antennae.
After selecting the tool, simply click anywhere on the artboard, click and drag to your desired size.
Copy and pasting can also come in handy here.
Use a few more overlapping ellipses to easily form the butterfly's body!
Connect the antennae to the butterfly's head, using either the 'Line' tool or the 'Pen' tool.
With 2 clicks of the Pen Tool, you can create one antennae connection.
After that, copy and paste to apply the same line to the opposing antennae.
Cleaning Up and Filling In Review what you have so far.
The graphic looks a but basic and cluttered with all of the overlapping lines, don't you think?
That can be fixed by adding 'Fill' colors to the shapes and removing/recoloring the outlines or 'Stroke'.
Select each of the segments that made up the butterfly and add fills of color.
You might use brown with a slight red tint, as pictured here (RGB value: #6B4411).
You can also change the outline (stroke) color from black to the new brown.
In the case of the antennae connections, only the stroke needs to be modified.
Do the wings, too.
After applying the same treatment to the wings (this time using a dark red color: #B54B1D), you have a fully colorized digital butterfly!
Use gradient, if desired.
This more advanced technique can be applied to fills to create a more natural or interesting colorization.
For each wing, you can apply a 'Radial Gradient' combining two colors (a yellow: #D3D400 with a red: #B54B1D) to produce a more naturally colored pair of wings.
Check out the final product!
